questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of progressive tingling and weakness in both legs. The patient reports that he has difficulty walking. Two weeks ago, he had bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps that resolved spontaneously after 5 days. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows weakness in the lower extremities with absent deep tendon reflexes. Reflexes are 1+ in the upper extremities. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact. Romberg test is negative. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis results show:


Opening pressure
normal


Protein
200 mg/dL


Glucose
70 mg/dL


White blood cells
4/mm3


This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with vitamin B12 deficiency can develop neuropsychiatric complications, including dementia and depression. This patient's paresthesias in both legs might suggest subacute combined degeneration (SACD) as a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency. However, sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact and the patient has ascending flaccid paralysis as well as a negative Romberg test, all of which would not be consistent with SACD.

B) INCORRECT:

Disorders of the thymus like thymoma or thymic hyperplasia occur in many patients with myasthenia gravis (MG). MG typically causes muscle weakness, but smaller muscles responsible for fine movements tend to be affected first (e.g., the eye muscles, causing ptosis and/or diplopia), while larger muscles such as those in the proximal limbs become affected later on. Also, muscle weakness in patients with MG usually worsens throughout the day and improves with rest, while this patient's symptoms show acute progression without remission. Furthermore, MG affects the neuromuscular junction, meaning it is purely a motor disorder that would not explain this patient's tingling sensation.
Image Description:

Chest CT (axial section; IV contrast)

A large, hypointense anterior mediastinal mass (B), which is likely a thymoma, is visible adjacent to the pulmonary artery (C).

A: ascending aorta; D: left main bronchus; E: descending aorta; F: superior vena cava

C) INCORRECT:

Urinary incontinence is common in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). In contrast to the features seen in this patient, MS is characterized by symptoms of demyelination of the CNS, such as hyperreflexia and spasticity. Also, the age of onset is usually 20–40 years, making it less likely in this 54-year-old man. Patients with GBS often have symptoms of autonomic dysfunction, e.g., tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, orthostatic hypotension, ileus, or urinary retention. Urinary incontinence, on the other hand, is not a typical feature of GBS.

D) CORRECT:

A common and often devastating complication of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is respiratory failure, which can result if the ascending paralysis involves the respiratory muscles. For this reason, it is crucial to monitor respiratory function through frequent assessment of vital capacity, as up to 30% of patients require mechanical ventilation. While the majority of patients with GBS fully recover over time, approx. 5% of patients with GBS die because of acute complications such as respiratory paralysis, pulmonary infection, pulmonary embolism, or cardiac dysfunction. Treatment options include high doses of intravenous immunoglobulins or plasmapheresis.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a common finding in patients with Friedreich ataxia (FA). While this patient has some features of FA (abnormal gait, bilateral lower extremity weakness, loss of DTRs), the age of onset (peak incidence 8–15 years), lack of a family history of a genetic disorder, and the acute progression following a gastrointestinal infection, as well as the finding of albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis, make FA unlikely.
questions.hint: Paresthesias affecting distal extremities and symmetric ascending flaccid paralysis in combination with the laboratory findings (CSF with a high protein level but normal WBCs, i.e., albuminocytologic dissociation) is highly suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS is commonly associated with a preceding Campylobacter enteritis, which is consistent with this patient's history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because he has not been able to walk since waking up that morning. His mother said that when he tried to get out of bed he was unable to stand without support. He also complained of a prickling sensation in his hands and feet. Three weeks ago, he had a fever, dry cough, and a sore throat. The fever and sore throat subsided a week after they began, but the cough has persisted. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is severe weakness in both lower extremities and sensation is mildly decreased in the hands and feet. Knee and ankle jerk reflexes are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.0 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6000/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
64%


Eosinophils
2%


Lymphocytes
26%


Monocytes
7%


Platelet count
160,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
27 mm/h


Serum



Na+

138 mEq/L


Cl-

101 mEq/L


K+

4.9 mEq/L


HCO3-

26 mEq/L


Ca2+

9.7 mg/dL


Creatine kinase
93 U/L


A lumbar puncture is performed; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 2/mm3, a glucose concentration of 60 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 91 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin and cefotaxime (or another third-generation cephalosporin) can be used in combination as the empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis in children > 1 month old and adults < 50 years old. The classic triad of meningitis includes fever, headaches, and neck stiffness, none of which is currently seen in this patient. Although meningitis may cause focal neurological deficits, it would not manifest with ascending paralysis. In addition, CSF analysis in bacterial meningitis typically shows granulocytosis, decreased glucose concentration, and elevated protein; albuminocytologic dissociation is not characteristic of this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis (MG). Although MG also causes muscular weakness, it typically manifests in adults and involves weakness of the ocular (diplopia), bulbar (dysphagia), and proximal limb muscles. Most importantly, MG does not cause any sensory symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Treatment for GBS consists of high-dose IVIG, supportive therapy, and, in some cases, plasmapheresis. The exact mechanism by which IVIG improves symptoms is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve an interaction with the immune cells and the subsequent normalization of the immune response. If left untreated, patients with GBS can develop severe paralysis, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., asystole, bradycardia, tachyarrhythmias) and respiratory insufficiency, resulting in the need for subsequent intubation and mechanical ventilation. Because paralysis can spread quickly, monitoring cardiac and respiratory function is absolutely vital.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) are used in the treatment of transverse myelitis (TM), which can occur following a viral infection and manifests with acute or subacute quadriparesis and sensory disturbances. However, in patients with TM who have quadriparesis, the upper and lower extremities would be equally affected (unlike the predominant lower extremity involvement in this patient). There would also be a clear sensory level that is concordant with the motor deficits in a patient with TM, whereas this patient has no clearly discernable sensory level. In addition, CSF pleocytosis is a characteristic feature of TM, which is not seen here, and TM usually manifests in the 2nd and 4th decades of life, not the 1st decade.

Because of the immune-mediated origin of GBS, corticosteroids were formerly believed to be an effective treatment. However, recent studies have shown that treatment with corticosteroids is not beneficial in GBS and may even be associated with worse outcomes. The only exception is in the chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) variant of GBS, as corticosteroids are an effective treatment in this disorder; however, CIDP progresses slowly (typically over > 2 months) and therefore is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Botulism antitoxin is used in the treatment of botulism, which manifests with descending paralysis – not ascending paralysis. Botulism is not associated with a recent URTI; instead, recent consumption of canned foods, honey (in infants), or IV drug use would be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous acyclovir is used for treating HSV encephalitis, which manifests with neurological symptoms such as focal deficits, seizures, altered mental status, and behavioral changes. However, bilateral ascending paralysis and sensory disturbances would not be expected.

G) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant that may be used to treat neuropathic pain in GBS. The majority of patients with GBS develop neuropathic pain that requires treatment during the course of the disease. However, gabapentin is not the first step in management and treatment should not be initiated until neuropathic pain occurs.
questions.hint: The acute onset of ascending paralysis, paresthesia in the hands and feet, and absent muscle reflexes 3 weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) indicates Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). Albuminocytologic dissociation in the CSF supports the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of rapidly progressive weakness of his legs and an inability to walk since that morning. He reports that he felt a tingling sensation in his feet yesterday before the weakness set in. He was sent home early from a school trip 2 weeks ago because he had a fever, runny nose, and a cough, which all resolved without treatment. Examination shows a mild, symmetrical decrease in sensation in the legs and absent ankle and patellar reflexes. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient?



Opening pressure (mm H2O)
Glucose (mg/dL)
Protein (mg/dL)
White blood cell count (/mm3)




A
120
50
50
400


B
350
20
350
3000


C
350
20
50
25


D
120
50
30
3


E
120
50
550
3
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These CSF findings are consistent with viral meningitis (e.g., due to infection with an enterovirus), not GBS. In viral meningitis, the elevated cell count shows lymphocytic predominance. Although an upper respiratory tract infection can precede or accompany viral meningitis, this patient's infection resolved, and he does not have typical manifestations of meningitis (e.g., fever, headache, neck stiffness). Moreover, viral meningitis is not associated with ascending paralysis, symmetric peripheral paresthesias, or absent muscle reflexes.

B) INCORRECT:

These CSF findings are consistent with bacterial meningitis (in this patient's age group, most commonly due to Neisseria meningitidis), not GBS. In bacterial meningitis, the elevated cell count shows neutrophilic predominance. Although an upper respiratory tract infection can precede bacterial meningitis, this patient's infection resolved, and he does not have typical manifestations of meningitis (e.g., fever, headache, neck stiffness). Moreover, bacterial meningitis is not associated with ascending paralysis, symmetric peripheral paresthesias, or absent muscle reflexes.

C) INCORRECT:

These CSF findings are consistent with fungal meningitis (e.g., due to an infection with Cryptococcus spp.), not GBS. In fungal meningitis, the elevated cell count shows lymphocytic predominance and the opening pressure is increased. Although this patient was febrile recently, his infection resolved, and he does not have the fever, headache, or meningeal signs that are typically seen in patients with meningitis. Moreover, fungal meningitis is very rare in immunocompetent individuals and is not associated with ascending paralysis, symmetrical peripheral paresthesias, or absent muscle reflexes.

D) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with a normal CSF analysis. GBS, however, manifests with pathologic CSF changes.

E) CORRECT:

This CSF analysis shows a large increase in protein without a similar increase in WBC count (< 10), a condition called albuminocytologic dissociation. It results from a dysfunction of the blood-brain barrier and is a hallmark finding of GBS. This patient's symptoms are caused by a postinfectious autoimmune reaction that generates cross-reactive antibodies against gangliosides (e.g., anti‑GM1 antibodies) or other unknown antigens of peripheral Schwann cells, which leads to segmental demyelination and axonal degeneration (see “Cerebrospinal fluid analysis” table).

GBS is treated with supportive care, particularly cardiac and respiratory support, as the ascending paralysis progresses. Disease-modifying treatment consists of high-dose IV immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis. Up to 70% of patients have a good prognosis, with symptoms resolving in the reverse order of their development.
questions.hint: The development of rapidly progressive paralysis with symmetrical peripheral paresthesias and absent muscle reflexes 2 weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection is highly suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea that began 12 hours ago. Three days ago, she ate undercooked chicken at a local restaurant. Blood cultures grow spiral and comma-shaped, oxidase-positive organisms at 42°C. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Segmental myelin degeneration is the hallmark of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). It is hypothesized that the inciting infection prompts the development of antibodies with cross-reactivity to antigens on Schwann cells. This molecular mimicry results in damage to the myelin sheaths of peripheral nerves. Campylobacter jejuni enteritis is classically associated with GBS.

B) INCORRECT:

Seizures can occur as a result of electrolyte imbalances in cases of profuse diarrhea (e.g., due to Vibrio cholerae infection). Vibrio cholerae is also oxidase-positive and comma-shaped but infection is typically contracted after eating undercooked seafood, and classically presents with copious watery diarrhea (“rice water diarrhea”), not bloody diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a serious complication of Clostridioides difficile colitis and also presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, the vast majority of patients with toxic megacolon caused by C. difficile have a history of recent antibiotic exposure. Moreover, C. difficile is a gram-positive, oxidase-negative, and obligate anaerobe bacillus that forms spores, unlike the spiral and comma-shaped, oxidase-positive organism found in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema nodosum can be a complication of Yersinia enterocolitica gastroenteritis, which can also present with abdominal pain and bloody or watery diarrhea after consumption of undercooked meat. However, Y. enterocolitica is an oxidase-negative pathogen that can grow at refrigeration temperatures (3–5 °C), unlike the pathogen seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Peyer patch necrosis can occur as a complication of typhoid fever and lead to profuse rectal bleeding. Infection with Salmonella typhi is via the fecal-oral route and would not be due to consumption of undercooked poultry. This infection develops over a period of weeks and is initially characterized by a fluctuating temperature with malaise, followed by profound fatigue and high fevers. Diarrhea is a relatively late finding. Moreover, Salmonella typhi is an oxidase-negative pathogen, unlike the oxidase-positive organism found in this patient.
questions.hint: Campylobacter jejuni is a spiral and comma-shaped, oxidase-positive organism that grows at 42°C and is a common cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea. It is associated with consumption of undercooked meat, especially poultry.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of tingling and weakness in the lower extremities. Neurologic examination shows areflexia of the ankle and knee joints bilaterally. Motor strength is 1/5 in both lower legs. Over the next 3 weeks, the patient's condition progresses to involve both upper extremities, and she requires ventilatory support. Six weeks after admission, deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the ankles, and she is able to wiggle her toes. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the improvement in this patient's neurological status?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The synthesis of monoamine neurotransmitters is impaired in patients with neuropsychiatric disorders such as major depressive disorder. Neurotransmitter synthesis is not involved in the recovery process from Guillain-Barré syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

The underlying pathology of Guillain-Barré syndrome is a postinfectious, autoimmune reaction that generates cross-reactive antibodies that demyelinate peripheral nerve axons. Disease progression peaks 2–4 weeks after the onset of symptoms. Peripheral nerve axons then undergo remyelination by Schwann cells over a duration of weeks to months, and symptoms recede in reverse order of their development (i.e., functionality is restored in a descending pattern, in contrast to the ascending pattern of paralysis).

In addition to supportive management, high doses of intravenous immunoglobulins and plasmapheresis can be used to shorten the time to recovery.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrocyte precursor cells replicate during the recovery process after an exacerbation of multiple sclerosis, a condition that causes hyperreflexia (not the hyporeflexia seen in this case). Oligodendrocytes synthesize myelin in the central nervous system and are not involved in the recovery process from Guillain-Barré syndrome, which affects the peripheral nervous system.

D) INCORRECT:

The accumulation of S-adenosylmethionine is part of the underlying pathology of peripheral neuropathy caused by vitamin B6 deficiency, a condition that can be induced by isoniazid therapy and oral contraceptive use. It is not involved in the recovery process from Guillain-Barré syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytic infiltration in the endoneurium of peripheral nerves is part of the underlying pathology of Guillain-Barré syndrome. This autoimmune reaction generates cross-reactive antibodies that damage peripheral nerve axons. Lymphocytic infiltration is not involved in the recovery process from this condition.
questions.hint: This patient had Guillain-Barré syndrome, a condition that causes acute-onset distal paresthesias with symmetrical, ascending lower motor neuron weakness.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of facial drooping since this morning. Over the past 6 days, he has had lower back pain, weakness of his legs, and tingling in his hands and feet. Five weeks ago, he was diagnosed with HIV infection and has started antiretroviral therapy with lamivudine, abacavir, and efavirenz.  He does not smoke. He drinks three to four beers on weekends. He is alert and fully oriented. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a blank facial expression and bilateral drooping of the mouth. The patient is unable to frown. There is decreased sensation to light touch of the tongue. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the lower extremities and deep tendon reflexes are diminished bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick of the feet and ankles is decreased bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ count of 700 cells/μL. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

GBS is a clinical diagnosis that is supported by electrodiagnostic studies (e.g., nerve conduction studies, electromyography) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis. Electrodiagnostic studies usually show signs of demyelination (e.g., conduction blocks, temporal dispersion), while CSF analysis shows albuminocytologic dissociation. Most patients have an acute upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection prior to the onset of GBS. This infection triggers the formation of cross‑reactive autoantibodies that attack the host's own axonal antigens. Similarly, HIV infection can also cause GBS, especially in patients who are not yet immunocompromised.

B) INCORRECT:

GQ1b ganglioside is selectively expressed in the cranial nerves that innervate the extraocular muscles (i.e., CN III, IV, and VI). Autoimmune reactions with antibody formation against GQ1b ganglioside result in nerve inflammation and extraocular muscle weakness. Consequently, a serum GQ1b antibody assay is used to diagnose GBS variants that manifest with ophthalmoplegia (e.g., postoperative GBS, Miller-Fisher syndrome). As this patient does not present with ophthalmoplegia, GQ1b antibodies are unlikely to be present.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for protein levels and cell counts is performed to support the diagnosis of GBS, but CSF cultures are not required. CSF cultures are used to identify the pathogen when fungal or bacterial meningitis is suspected. In patients with GBS, CSF analysis usually shows elevated CSF protein with a normal white blood cell count (i.e., albuminocytologic dissociation). However, in patients with GBS and concurrent HIV infection, cytology may show CSF pleocytosis rather than a normal white blood cell count.

D) INCORRECT:

An urgent MRI of the spine with contrast is indicated for patients with acute lower back pain and bilateral flaccid paralysis to identify emergencies such as compressive myelopathies (e.g., epidural abscess, hemorrhage, malignancies), spinal cord inflammation, or spinal cord infarcts. However, the combination of ascending bilateral peripheral weakness and cranial nerve deficits seen in this patient is consistent with GBS and would not be explained by a spinal cord lesion. While an MRI of the spine may show intrathecal spinal nerve root thickening and enhancement in patients with GBS, these findings are nonspecific, and therefore, nondiagnostic.

E) INCORRECT:

An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) can be used as a screening test for early disseminated Lyme disease, which can manifest with neurological symptoms, such as paresthesias, paresis, and bilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy. However, this patient does not have other symptoms of early disseminated Lyme disease, such as meningitis, carditis, or migratory arthralgia. Another diagnosis is more likely in a patient with ascending symmetrical weakness and recently diagnosed HIV infection.
questions.hint: The progressive development of bilateral, symmetrical weakness, hyporeflexia, and paresthesia in the ankles and feet, together with cranial nerve deficits and back pain (due to nerve root inflammation) in a patient with recently diagnosed HIV infection is suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of progressive double vision and difficulty keeping his eyes open. He says that his symptoms are present throughout the day. Two weeks ago, he was diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection, the symptoms of which have since resolved. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks one glass of wine nightly with dinner. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 112/78 mm Hg. There is ptosis bilaterally and horizontal ocular movement is restricted in both eyes. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Neurologic examination shows normal muscle strength, bulk, and tone. Deep tendon reflexes are absent throughout. Sensation is intact. Romberg test is positive. His gait is wide-based. Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing and fundoscopic examination show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pretectal brain lesions (e.g., pinealoma, posterior cerebral artery occlusion) may cause Parinaud syndrome, which can manifest with ptosis and gaze palsy. However, patients classically present with vertical rather than horizontal gaze palsy and also develop eyelid retraction, convergence-retraction nystagmus, and light-near dissociation, none of which are seen here. In addition, areflexia, gait ataxia, and a positive Romberg test are not characteristic of Parinaud syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), a paraneoplastic syndrome most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer, can manifest with hyporeflexia in a patient with a long history of smoking. However, findings such as ophthalmoplegia, wide-based gait, and a positive Romberg test are not characteristic of LEMS. In addition, most patients develop proximal muscle weakness and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation). Finally, patients typically show improvement in strength and reflex activity with repeated use and/or stimulation from daily activities, whereas this patient's symptoms are present throughout the day.

C) CORRECT:

MFS is a rare variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in which molecular mimicry between antigens of infectious agents (e.g., Haemophilus influenzae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus) and the ganglioside components GQ1b and GT1a of cranial and peripheral nerves results in a cross-reactive immune response. As in GBS, symptoms typically develop 1–3 weeks after a previous upper respiratory tract infection or gastrointestinal infection. The resulting axonal degeneration manifests as a triad of external ophthalmoplegia (combined or isolated cranial nerve III, IV, and VI palsies), ataxia, and areflexia. Pupillary defects can also occur and, in up to 25% of MFS cases, peripheral nerve involvement leads to weakness of the extremities. Detection on serological testing of anti-GQ1b antibodies, which are specific to MFS, confirms the diagnosis. The disease course is typically self-limited and the treatment is generally supportive. However, in patients with severe symptoms (e.g., swallowing or respiratory difficulties), intravenous immune globulin and/or plasmapheresis can be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetylcholine receptor antibodies are seen in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG), which can manifest with diplopia, ptosis, and ophthalmoplegia, and can also be exacerbated by a previous infection. However, findings such as a wide-based gait, positive Romberg test, and absent reflexes are not characteristic of MG.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke encephalopathy, which most commonly develops in patients with a history of chronic alcohol use and can manifest with ophthalmoplegia, gait ataxia, and a positive Romberg test. However, areflexia is not characteristic, and patients most commonly present with confusion, which is not seen here. In addition, this patient has no known risk factors for thiamine deficiency (e.g., chronic heavy alcohol use, starvation, malabsorption); his alcohol consumption is considered moderate.
questions.hint: This patient's triad of ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and areflexia suggests Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS).

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is hospitalized after experiencing weakness in his lower extremities for 2 days. His symptoms, which started with weakness and paresthesias in the toes on both feet, spread to his thighs within a day and are now severe enough that he is using a wheelchair. He had a diarrheal illness a week before the onset of these neurologic symptoms.
On examination, the patient is afebrile, and his blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation are normal. Strength testing results are 1/5 in all major muscle groups of both lower extremities and 4/5 in the upper extremities. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are absent.
Cerebrospinal fluid testing reveals a total protein level of 200 mg/dL (reference range, 15–45) and a leukocyte count of 2 cells per mm3 .
Infection with which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Other pathogens commonly involved in GBS include cytomegalovirus, influenza virus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumonia; however, Campylobacter is the most common.

B) INCORRECT:

West Nile virus usually causes a febrile illness and may cause encephalitis, meningitis, or flaccid paralysis but is not associated with GBS.

C) CORRECT:

The development of an acute, flaccid, symmetric, ascending paralysis with paresthesias is characteristic of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS is an autoimmune, inflammatory, demyelinative polyradiculoneuropathy that occurs worldwide in any season, affecting approximately 1.5 people per 100,000 annually. Weakness is the most common presenting symptom, typically involving the proximal leg muscles first, then the trunk, intercostal, arm, neck, and cranial muscles. These symptoms are often accompanied by pain and aching in muscles, sensory signs and symptoms, and autonomic disturbances.

In two-thirds of cases, a respiratory or gastrointestinal illness precedes the onset of weakness by 1 to 3 weeks. An estimated 30% of GBS cases are attributable to antecedent infection (usually 1–2 weeks) with Campylobacter species. In the United States, about 1 in 1000 patients with Campylobacter-related enteritis develops GBS. The likely cause is the formation of antibodies to epitopes on the infecting Campylobacter strain that are cross-reactive to GM1 ganglioside. There is no known preventive strategy to reduce the risk of this complication.

Other pathogens commonly involved in GBS include cytomegalovirus, influenza virus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumonia; however, Campylobacter is the most common.

Key learning point: The development of Guillain-Barré syndrome is often associated with an antecedent intestinal infection with Campylobacter species (jejuni or coli).

D) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum is not associated with GBS. Botulism, caused by C. botulinum, is usually characterized by cranial neuropathies and descending motor weakness, without sensory symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Salmonella can, on rare occasions, cause a transverse myelitis that may manifest acutely with low tone and loss of reflexes, this condition is much rarer than Campylobacter-related GBS.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man reports a 3-day history of progressive fatigue and numbness and tingling in his feet. He also reports some dyspnea on exertion during the past day.
He has a heart rate of 106 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 110/75 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while he is breathing ambient air. He has difficulty holding air in his cheeks, but the cranial nerves are otherwise unremarkable.
Motor examination is normal, except for mild distal weakness in the legs (4+/5 in ankle and toe dorsiflexion bilaterally). Reflexes are diminished at the ankles but normal elsewhere. Sensory, coordination, and gait examinations are normal. No other abnormalities are evident on physical examination.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Measurement of vital capacity and maximal inspiratory pressure
MRI of the brain and spinal cord

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture and an electromyography/nerve-conduction study during the first 1 to 2 weeks of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) symptom onset are helpful if they reveal classic features of GBS; they are not helpful if normal. Each is less important than urgent evaluation for pending respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.

B) CORRECT:

The classic manifestations of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) include ascending paralysis and areflexia. Paresthesias, pain, and facial paralysis are also common on initial presentation. Up to 10% of patients with GBS initially have normal reflexes. Within the first week of the illness, lumbar puncture and electromyography/nerve-conduction study are normal in as many as 50% of cases. Cytoalbuminologic dissociation in the cerebrospinal fluid (elevated protein but normal leukocyte count) is not always present, especially early in the disease course.

Patients with suspected GBS should be evaluated for respiratory function (e.g., mean inspiratory force and vital capacity) because catastrophic respiratory failure can occur quickly, even in patients (such as this one) who have normal oxygen saturation. Patients are usually hospitalized for evaluation and monitoring. Those with dysautonomia and respiratory failure should be monitored in an intensive care unit.

Key learning point: Acute onset of progressive dyspnea and paresthesias, along with evidence of diminished reflexes on physical examination, is most consistent with a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture and an electromyography/nerve-conduction study during the first 1 to 2 weeks of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) symptom onset are helpful if they reveal classic features of GBS; they are not helpful if normal. Each is less important than urgent evaluation for pending respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening. Progressive symptoms after a normal electromyography/nerve-conduction study should prompt a follow-up study.

D) INCORRECT:

Once respiratory function is stabilized, HIV serology testing may be useful, as patients with HIV infection may present with a Guillain-Barré syndrome-like syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain and spinal cord may be useful in distinguishing Guillain-Barré syndrome from brainstem encephalitis and transverse myelitis, but it is less urgent than evaluation for pending respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man was hospitalized 6 months ago with a 2-week history of progressive bilateral leg weakness and numbness and was diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome. He was treated with plasma exchange and began to experience symptomatic improvement within 2 weeks.
Since discharge 5 months ago, his symptoms have slowly and steadily improved, although his balance has not completely returned. He has continued to experience occasional mechanical falls but has not sustained any injuries as a result of these falls.
The only abnormalities on physical examination are absence of ankle jerks bilaterally, absence of vibration and proprioception in the ankles and toes bilaterally, and the presence of bilateral foot drop.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Start additional treatment with plasma exchange
Refer for orthotics and physical therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prednisone may be considered in treating chronic inflammatory immune-mediated demyelinating polyneuropathy, but it has no role in treating Guillain-Barré syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Plasma exchange and administration of intravenous immunoglobulin have similar efficacy when given in the acute phase of Guillain-Barré syndrome, but these treatments have no role in the recovery period.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasma exchange and administration of intravenous immunoglobulin have similar efficacy when given in the acute phase of Guillain-Barré syndrome, but these treatments have no role in the recovery period.

D) INCORRECT:

Natalizumab is a disease-modifying medicine used to treat patients with multiple sclerosis but is not indicated in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Although the majority of patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome have an excellent prognosis, recovery may take many months or even years, and up to 20% of patients will have persistent disability. Some patients may even have worsening of symptoms after immunotherapy, known as treatment-related fluctuations. Physical therapy and orthoses play an important role in the care of patients with persistent peripheral neuropathy.

Key learning point: The appropriate management of persistent foot drop following treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome consists of orthotics and physical therapy.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy reports a 3-day history of progressive fatigue and numbness and tingling in his feet. He also reports some dyspnea on exertion during the past day.
He has a heart rate of 106 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 110/75 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while he is breathing ambient air. He has difficulty holding air in his cheeks, but the cranial nerves are otherwise unremarkable.
Motor examination is normal, except for mild distal weakness in the legs (4+/5 in ankle and toe dorsiflexion bilaterally). Reflexes are diminished at the ankles but normal elsewhere. Sensory, coordination, and gait examinations are normal. No other abnormalities are evident on physical examination.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Measurement of vital capacity and maximal inspiratory pressure
MRI of the brain and spinal cord

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture and an electromyography/nerve-conduction study during the first 1 to 2 weeks of GBS symptom onset are helpful if they reveal classic features of GBS; they are not helpful if normal. Each is less important than urgent evaluation for pending respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening. Progressive symptoms after a normal electromyography/nerve-conduction study should prompt a follow-up study.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture and an electromyography/nerve-conduction study during the first 1 to 2 weeks of GBS symptom onset are helpful if they reveal classic features of GBS; they are not helpful if normal. Each is less important than urgent evaluation for pending respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening. Progressive symptoms after a normal electromyography/nerve-conduction study should prompt a follow-up study.

C) CORRECT:

The classic manifestations of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) include ascending paralysis and areflexia. Paresthesias, pain, and facial paralysis are also common on initial presentation. Up to 10% of patients with GBS initially have normal reflexes. Within the first week of the illness, lumbar puncture and electromyography/nerve-conduction study are normal in as many as 50% of cases. Cytoalbuminologic dissociation in the cerebrospinal fluid (elevated protein but normal leukocyte count) is not always present, especially early in the disease course.

Patients with suspected GBS should be evaluated for respiratory function (e.g., mean inspiratory force and vital capacity) because catastrophic respiratory failure can occur quickly, even in patients (such as this one) who have normal oxygen saturation. Patients are usually hospitalized for evaluation, supportive care, and monitoring. Those with dysautonomia and respiratory failure should be monitored in an intensive care unit.

Key learning point: Acute onset of progressive dyspnea and paresthesias, along with evidence of diminished reflexes on physical examination, is most consistent with a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain and spinal cord may be useful in distinguishing GBS from brainstem encephalitis and transverse myelitis, but it is less urgent than evaluation for pending respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.

E) INCORRECT:

Once respiratory function is stabilized, HIV serology testing may be useful, as patients with HIV infection may present with a GBS-like syndrome.

questions.text:
A young man, 18 years of age, is hospitalized after experiencing weakness in his lower extremities for 2 days. His symptoms, which started with weakness and paresthesias in the toes on both feet, spread to his thighs within a day and are now severe enough that he is using a wheelchair. He had a diarrheal illness a week before the onset of these neurologic symptoms.
On examination, the patient is afebrile, and his blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation are normal. Strength testing results are 1/5 in all major muscle groups of both lower extremities and 4/5 in the upper extremities. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are absent.
Cerebrospinal fluid testing reveals a total protein level of 200 mg/dL (reference range, 15–45) and a leukocyte count of 2 cells per mm3 .
Infection with which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salmonella is not associated with GBS.

B) INCORRECT:

West Nile virus is not associated with GBS. West Nile virus usually causes a febrile illness and may cause encephalitis, meningitis, or flaccid paralysis.

C) CORRECT:

The development of an acute, flaccid, symmetric, ascending paralysis with paresthesias is characteristic of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS is an autoimmune, inflammatory, demyelinative polyradiculoneuropathy that occurs worldwide in any season, affecting approximately 1.5 people per 100,000 annually. Weakness is the most common presenting symptom, typically involving the proximal leg muscles first, then the trunk, intercostal, arm, neck, and cranial muscles. These symptoms are often accompanied by pain and aching in muscles, sensory signs and symptoms, and autonomic disturbances.

In two-thirds of cases, a respiratory or gastrointestinal illness precedes the onset of weakness by 1 to 3 weeks. An estimated 30% of GBS cases are attributable to antecedent infection (usually 1–2 weeks) with Campylobacter species. In the United States, about 1 in 1000 patients with Campylobacter-related enteritis develops GBS. The likely cause is the formation of antibodies to epitopes on the infecting Campylobacter strain that are cross-reactive to GM1 ganglioside. There is no known preventive strategy to reduce the risk of this complication.

Other pathogens commonly involved in GBS include cytomegalovirus, influenza virus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumonia; however, Campylobacter is the most common.

Key learning point: The development of Guillain-Barré syndrome is often associated with an antecedent intestinal infection with Campylobacter species (jejuni or coli).

D) INCORRECT:

Other pathogens commonly involved in GBS include cytomegalovirus, influenza virus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumonia; however, Campylobacter is the most common.

E) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum is not associated with GBS. Botulism, caused by C. botulinum, is usually characterized by cranial neuropathies and descending motor weakness, without sensory symptoms.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy who eats a pescatarian diet and has generally been healthy develops tingling in his feet. Twenty-four hours after onset, he presents to the emergency department (ED), where he is diagnosed with anxiety, reassured, and sent home. Four days later, he returns to the ED because he is unable to walk. He reports back pain, burning pain that starts in his feet and extends up to his knees, and tingling in his hands.
On examination, his vital signs are all stable. He is weak, distally more than proximally, and his patellar and Achilles reflexes are absent. He recalls a viral illness 3 weeks ago. He undergoes lumbar puncture, which reveals an elevated protein level and normal leukocyte count.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is a fibrinolytic therapy used to dissolve clots that are causing a central nervous system (CNS) stroke. This patient does not show any CNS focality concerning for stroke (i.e., unilateral weakness, cranial nerve palsy, or asymmetric reflexes). A spinal cord infarct is less likely in the setting of distal tingling and ascending paralysis (which suggests a peripheral or neuropathic origin).

B) CORRECT:

This patient likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS; also known as acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy [AIDP]), an ascending paralysis thought to be caused by a T-cell-mediated autoimmune response to an infectious antigen that cross-reacts with the myelin sheath (most commonly) or the axon.

Recognizing GBS

Symptoms of GBS start with numbness, tingling, and/or burning pain in the feet and hands (stocking-glove distribution), usually symmetric and ascending from distal to proximal, over the course of days. About 60% of affected patients report a gastrointestinal or respiratory illness 1 to 3 weeks before symptom onset. Campylobacter jejuni has been implicated, especially in the axonal variant.

Depending on the nerves involved, symptoms of GBS may be motor, sensory, or both. Reduced or absent reflexes are evident on examination. Weakness can progress rapidly, involving bulbar and respiratory muscles with dysautonomia. A negative inspiratory force (NIF) of <30 mL of water or an FVC of <15–20 mL/kg indicates the need for intubation. Changes in oxygen saturation occur later and are not an effective monitoring parameter.

Cerebrospinal fluid analysis typically reveals albuminocytologic dissociation (an elevation in the protein level but not the leukocyte count).

Treating GBS

GBS can be treated with either intravenous immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis. The two interventions are considered equally effective.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome is intravenous immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) is the treatment for beriberi (neuropathy related to thiamine deficiency) and Wernicke encephalopathy, which is most commonly observed in patients with chronic alcohol use. Given this patient’s physical findings, history of recent viral illness, and absence of reported nutritional deficit, GBS is a more likely diagnosis than thiamine deficiency. Although very restrictive diets may lead to thiamine deficiency, this patient’s pescatarian diet would not be a risk factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous glucocorticoids have not shown benefit in GBS. Glucocorticoids are used in acute cord compression or transverse myelitis. Absent reflexes may initially be observed in patients with spinal cord shock, but in the setting of symmetric ascending paralysis, polyneuropathy is a more likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin is useful in alleviating neuropathic symptoms such as pain or burning but does not treat the underlying autoimmune etiology of GBS.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of progressive tingling and weakness in both legs. Two weeks ago, he had bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps that resolved spontaneously after 5 days. Examination shows weakness in the lower extremities with absent deep tendon reflexes. Reflexes are 1+ in the upper extremities. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact. Romberg test is negative. Laboratory studies show:


Cerebrospinal fluid



Opening pressure
normal


Protein
200 mg/dL


Glucose
70 mg/dL


White blood cells
4/mm3


This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with vitamin B12 deficiency can develop neuropsychiatric complications, including dementia and depression. This patient's paresthesias in both legs might suggest subacute combined degeneration (SACD) as a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency. However, sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact and the patient has ascending flaccid paralysis as well as a negative Romberg test, all of which would not be consistent with SACD.

B) INCORRECT:

Disorders of the thymus like thymoma or thymic hyperplasia occur in many patients with myasthenia gravis (MG). MG typically causes muscle weakness, but smaller muscles responsible for fine movements tend to be affected first (e.g., the eye muscles, causing ptosis and/or diplopia), while larger muscles such as those in the proximal limbs become affected later on. Also, muscle weakness in patients with MG usually worsens throughout the day and improves with rest, while this patient's symptoms show acute progression without remission. Furthermore, MG affects the neuromuscular junction, meaning it is purely a motor disorder that would not explain this patient's tingling sensation.
Image Description:

Chest CT (axial section; IV contrast)

A large, hypointense anterior mediastinal mass (B), which is likely a thymoma, is visible adjacent to the pulmonary artery (C).

A: ascending aorta; D: left main bronchus; E: descending aorta; F: superior vena cava

C) INCORRECT:

Urinary incontinence is common in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). In contrast to the features seen in this patient, MS is characterized by symptoms of demyelination of the CNS, such as hyperreflexia and spasticity. Also, the age of onset is usually 20–40 years, making it less likely in this 54-year-old man. Patients with GBS often have symptoms of autonomic dysfunction, e.g., tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, orthostatic hypotension, ileus, or urinary retention. Urinary incontinence, on the other hand, is not a typical feature of GBS.

D) CORRECT:

A common and often devastating complication of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is respiratory failure, which can result if the ascending paralysis involves the respiratory muscles. For this reason, it is crucial to monitor respiratory function through frequent assessment of vital capacity, as up to 30% of patients require mechanical ventilation. While the majority of patients with GBS fully recover over time, approx. 5% of patients with GBS die because of acute complications such as respiratory paralysis, pulmonary infection, pulmonary embolism, or cardiac dysfunction. Treatment options include high doses of intravenous immunoglobulins or plasmapheresis.

Key learning point: Guillain-Barré syndrome can cause life-threatening respiratory failure due to ascending paralysis involving the respiratory muscles, requiring close monitoring of pulmonary function.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a common finding in patients with Friedreich ataxia (FA). While this patient has some features of FA (bilateral lower extremity weakness, loss of DTRs), the age of onset (peak incidence 8–15 years), lack of a family history of a genetic disorder, and the acute progression following a gastrointestinal infection, as well as the finding of albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis, make FA unlikely.
questions.hint: Paresthesias affecting distal extremities and symmetric ascending flaccid paralysis in combination with the laboratory findings (CSF with a high protein level but normal WBCs, i.e., albuminocytologic dissociation) is highly suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS is commonly associated with a preceding Campylobacter enteritis, which is consistent with this patient's history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum is not associated with GBS. Botulism, caused by C. botulinum, is usually characterized by cranial neuropathies and descending motor weakness, without sensory symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Salmonella can, on rare occasions, cause a transverse myelitis that may manifest acutely with low tone and loss of reflexes, this condition is much rarer than Campylobacter-related GBS.
